conclusion: To determine when objects A and B are farthest apart, analyze their positions as functions of time.
The velocity-time graph shows the velocity of each object as a function of time.
The area under the velocity-time graph gives the displacement of the object from its starting position.
The displacement of an object at any time is given by the integral of its velocity from 0 to t.
For object A, velocity decreases from t=0 to t=t1, increases from t=t1 to t=t2, and is constant from t=t2 onwards.
For object B, velocity starts high, decreases to zero, and then increases again.
The farthest apart the two objects will be occurs when the difference in their displacements is maximized.
This happens when the areas under the curves for both objects are most different.
At t=t1, object A has a higher velocity than object B, but they have not yet diverged significantly.
At t=t2, the velocities of both objects are equal, and they are still close together.
After t=t2, object A continues to increase its velocity linearly, while object B also increases but at a slower rate.
The farthest apart the two objects will be is just before t=t2, where the difference in their velocities is the greatest.
The two objects are farthest apart at t = t1.
